modules.description: Provides functions to generate permalinks from an atom feed and entry, compare entries, and convert entries to HTML or Atom format. Works with atom feed metadata and entry records containing title, content, and identifiers. Used to render web views of individual entries and export them in standard atom format for syndication.

Generates XML elements for navigation components and buttons from pairs of strings and URIs. Processes lists of these pairs to construct structured HTML fragments like top, side, and bottom navigation bars. Accepts alignment parameters to control layout positioning.

Creates a structured sidebar component from a title and a list of content items, rendering them as XML elements. Operates on a recursive type representing sidebar entries and their nested contents. Used to generate navigational menus in web applications with hierarchical content organization.

Generates a navigation-based page layout by combining a top navigation bar with a main content area. It operates on HTML elements represented as `Cow.Html.t` values. Used to construct structured web pages with consistent navigation headers.

Generates blog post HTML elements using title, authors, date, and content, with structured URI handling. Constructs a blog template with title, subtitle, sidebar, posts section, and copyright. Works with strings, URIs, and Cow.Html.t for web content assembly.

Logs success messages with a custom formatter, handles not-found scenarios by generating appropriate responses, and manages redirects by constructing URL-based outputs. It operates on string-based messages and returns values of arbitrary type. Used to generate structured HTTP response messages in web applications.

type t = { id : string; title : string; updated : string; entries : Entry.t list } Provides functions to parse XML into feed structures, generate XML from feed data, and extract entry summaries. Operates on string-based timestamps, unique identifiers, and structured entry lists. Used to integrate with RSS readers and content aggregation systems by converting between external XML formats and internal data models.

Generates permalinks, compares entries, and converts between HTML and Atom formats using metadata and entry records. Supports title, content, and identifier manipulation for rendering and syndication. Allows exporting entries as Atom feeds or displaying them as HTML. Enables creation of web views and standardized content distribution.

Generates HTML body content with optional Google Analytics tracking, incorporating a title, headers, and main content. It operates on HTML fragments represented as `Cow.Html.t` and strings. Used to construct full web pages by embedding structured HTML elements into a predefined template.

Provides functions to convert months to short and long string representations, generate XML and HTML outputs, and construct and deconstruct date values. Works with integer-based month representations and a structured date type containing year, month, day, and time components. Used to format dates for web output, serialize data in XML, and manipulate date components in a structured way.

Handles structured message formatting and response generation for web applications, supporting success logs, not-found handling, and redirect construction. Processes string inputs and produces arbitrary output types, enabling flexible HTTP response creation. Examples include logging user actions, returning 404 errors, and redirecting to new URLs. Integrates seamlessly into request handling pipelines for dynamic web behavior.

Generates aggregated Atom feeds and HTML representations from multiple sources, handling blog, link, and wiki feeds. It processes Atom_feed.t values to produce entries, permalinks, and feed metadata. Used to combine individual feeds into a unified output for display or distribution.

Constructs web components by generating XML and HTML elements from structured data, including navigation bars, sidebars, and blog layouts. It handles recursive sidebar structures, aligns elements based on parameters, and combines top navigation with content areas. Operations involve processing pairs of strings and URIs, rendering hierarchical entries, and assembling blog templates with metadata. Examples include creating a side menu with nested items, generating a page with a top bar and main content, and building a blog with a sidebar and post listings.

Provides pre-defined HTTP header lists for common media types, including content-type and content-encoding pairs. Works with tuples of strings representing header fields and values. Used to quickly set appropriate response headers for serving HTML, JSON, images, and other file types in web applications.

Generates a permanent URL from an atom feed and a link, fetches an atom entry from a link using a feed, and compares links for ordering. It operates on link records and atom feeds, handling both individual links and lists of links. Used to construct atom feeds from a collection of links and to derive entry data from specific link sources.

Generates HTML from Atom authors, entries, and dates, and converts between Atom and internal entry formats. Processes date tuples, Atom feeds, and entry lists to produce structured HTML output. Constructs permalinks, recent updates summaries, and paginated views for web-based wiki interfaces.

Provides functions for rendering HTML templates with Zurb Foundation, handling page layouts, and generating navigation menus. Works with strings, lists, and custom page data structures representing blog posts and wiki entries. Used to build structured, responsive web interfaces for documentation and content management.

Manages feed data, HTML generation, and web component assembly by converting between XML, Atom, and HTML formats. Processes structured date types, entry records, and link metadata to build web pages, permalinks, and aggregated feeds. Supports date formatting, content rendering, and HTTP response creation with flexible output types. Enables tasks like generating blog layouts, exporting Atom feeds, and constructing HTML pages with tracking scripts.
